_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Executive Summary



Facility Description



Indian Head Division, Naval Surface Warfare Center carries out full spectrum functions for energetics research, development, manufacturing, testing, and in-service engineering.  Energetics are explosives, propellants, pyrotechnics, and specialty chemicals, including their immediately related component applications such as rocket and missile propulsion units; warheads; mines; gun projectiles and propelling charges; and cartridge actuated and propellant actuated devices.  The facility's scope of capabilities allow for the efficient use of specialized expertise and expensive facilities required for research and development, scale-up, manufacture, and test of energetics



Covered Processes



The facility has two nitration plants that produce various nitrate esters.  The nitration processes conducted by the plants differ slightly from each other, but both require mixed acid.  The main component of mixed acid is oleum, or fuming sulfuric acid.  Oleum is listed in the Clean Air Act of 1990, Section 112(r) as a toxic substance.  Both plants store oleum as a component of mixed acid in excess of the 10,000 pound threshold.  There are three mixed acid storage tanks in a diked area at building 781, three mixed acid storage tanks in a dike at building 3019, and finally two mixed acid storage tanks inside building 786. 



Covered Process 1:  Storage, Bldg. 781

Program Level:  3

Covered Chemical:  Oleum, CAS 8014-95-7

Maximum Quantity:  418,535 lb



Covered Process 2: Storage, Bldg. 3019

Program Level: 3

Covered Chemical:  Oleum, CAS 8014-95-7

Maximum Quantity:  100,426 lb



Covered Process 3:  Storage, Bldg. 786

Program Level:  1

Covered Chemical:  Oleum, CAS 8014-95-7

Maximum Quantity:  40,974 lb



5 Year Accident History



The facility has had no accidents involving a covered process in the last five years.



Prevention Program Overview



The following paragraphs present an overview of the facility's Risk Managemen

t Program.  The program is applicable to all covered processes at the facility. 



Process Safety Information



The material safety data sheet (MSDS) supplies the required safety information.  The Safety Department and the responsible office keep the MSDS.  Also, the cognizant office has the applicable piping and control diagrams.



Process Hazard Analysis



The facility has a process hazard analysis (PHA) for the covered storage tanks.  The PHA identified tank overfilling, valve problems, tank truck interface problems and supply line failures as the most likely causes of an accidental release.  Recommendations derived from the PHA have been incorporated into the process to eliminate or reduce the chance of an accidental release.  A hazard analysis is required for new explosive processes, facilities, and equipment; processes that have changed significantly; and processes that have not operated in the previous 2 years.  PHAs are conducted in accordance with MIL-STD-882 and Naval Sea Systems Command (NAVSEA) OP-5 Ammunition and Explosives Safety Ashore.



Operating Procedures



Operating procedures for the processing and handling of hazardous materials explicitly describe tasks to be performed and operating conditions to be maintained while performing specific processes.  The standard operating procedures (SOPs) include step-by-step process instructions, a hazardous material list, a safety equipment list, emergency response and contingency plans, and a hazard control briefing (HCB).  HCBs list and explain the hazards that may be encountered while performing the SOP, measures to avoid or minimize exposure to those hazards, symptoms that indicate unacceptable exposure to those hazards, and remedial actions required upon unacceptable exposure to those hazards.  HCBs are also presented to operating personnel prior to the start of a new operation, monthly for on-going operations, and when the SOP is changed.  SOPs also include a worker's statement that operating pers

onnel must sign to acknowledge their understanding of the SOP.  



Changes to an SOP are required when an operation is relocated, a new process is introduced, new physical or chemical actions are applied to energetic materials, explosive or personnel limits change or the waste stream increases or changes. SOP changes are reviewed for safety and environmental issues and are approved by the Safety Department head.  Minor process changes encompass all other situations and can be approved by the cognizant department head. 



All active SOPs are reviewed annually and must be re-approved every 4 years.  If an SOP is not re-approved within 4 years, the SOP becomes inactive.  Inactive SOPs are withdrawn from the operating area and all operations performed under that SOP are stopped until it is re-approved.



Training



This facility operates a personnel qualification/certification process in accordance with NAVSEA instruction 8020.9, "Ammunition and Explosives Personnel Qualification and Certification Program".  Personnel that come into contact with ammunition and explosives during the performance of a task, including the maintenance of processing equipment, must be certified to perform those tasks.  Personnel are eligible for certification when they have met qualifications such as demonstrating the skill and ability to perform tasks in a particular certification area.  The qualification requirement is documented as a proficiency demonstration using SOPs. There is a qualification/certification board that evaluates and recommends personnel for certification.



There are 2 levels of certification - team member (TM) and team leader (TL).  The TM level is the minimum level and applies in all normal operating certification areas.  The TL certification level applies in a specific certification area and allows the TL certified personnel to perform tasks independently and perform as process supervisor.  TM certified personnel must always be under the supervision of TL certifie

d personnel.  Certification is valid for 12 months.     

  

TM certified personnel are eligible for SOP in-training qualification so they can perform tasks under the supervision of TL certified personnel.  TM certified personnel are eligible for job specific training to attain the TL certified level for that certification area.  TL certified personnel are eligible for SOP qualification.  Both levels of SOP qualification are formal, documented declarations by the process supervisor and the subject personnel.



Qualification/certification records are kept in an automated personnel certification system (PCS) maintained by the Human Resources Department.  The PCS tracks medical, license and respirator qualifications and training. 



Mechanical Integrity



This facility has a computerized preventative maintenance (PM) management system.  The COMAC maintenance system issues PM requirements monthly and tracks performance records.  Flanges, piping, valves, pumps, and controls associated with the storage tanks are covered by the PM system.



Management of Change



The management of change is handled through the process review board (PRB), safety review committee (SRC), and the use of SOPs.  Actions subject to the management of change include the introduction of new explosive processes, facilities, and equipment; significant changes in processes; and start up of processes that have not operated in the previous 2 years.  See the section 'Operating Procedures' for a description of SOPs.  See the section 'Pre-Start Up Review' for a description of the PRB and SRC. 



Pre-Start Up Review



All new explosive processes, facilities, and equipment; processes that have changed significantly; and processes that have not operated in the previous 2 years must be validated as acceptable.  A process review board (PRB) or a safety review committee (SRC) are the mechanisms by which to receive validation. The PRB validation shows that the process can operate following the SOP to produ

ce the desired results while technical, security, quality, explosive safety, occupational safety and health (OSH), and environmental requirements are met. The SRC validation shows that the process can operate following the SOP while complying with explosive safety, OSH, and environmental requirements.



A PRB is required if: new processes are scaled-up over certain limits, new ingredients are added to an existing formulation, appreciable changes are made to an existing formulation, new facilities or equipment are used, existing facilities or equipment are modified, a process is restarted after an explosive incident or near-miss, a process is restarted after 2 or more years, and if there is any indication that a process presents a hazard not previously encountered.  The Safety Department has final say on whether a PRB or SRC is needed and can request a PRB.  The PRB is comprised of the Safety and Applied Technology Department heads, the Director of Quality, the cognizant department head, and any other personnel with specialized knowledge including environmental and safety representatives.  The PRB reviews information such as: process description, material flow, hazardous materials, hazard analysis, scale-up justification, facilities, equipment, SOPs, personnel training and qualification/certification plan, configuration management of process documents, and quality assurance plans.  The PRB recommendations are presented to the captain for final approval.  



The SRC reviews processes or changes that are deemed to not require a PRB.  The SRC typically consists of a safety representative and the cognizant project engineer, though other personnel are requested to participate when needed.  The SRC reviews information such as: process or change description, rationale for review at the SRC level, and the hazard analysis.  The SRC recommendations are presented to the cognizant division director and the Safety Department head. 



Additionally, the SOP is validated during a

pre-operational, and sometimes operational too, line check.

   

Incident Investigation



Two chapters of the facility's safety manual present the requirements and procedures for mishap investigations.  One outlines the procedures for investigating explosive incidents and another outlines the procedures for investigating personnel injuries and illnesses.  In both circumstances, near misses are treated as incidents and are therefore investigated.  The facility investigates and reports mishaps per Chief of Naval Operations instructions  (OPNAVINST) 5100.23 and 5102.1.  



Explosive incidents include inadvertent detonations, arming, and launches, malfunctions, material and equipment defects, calibration failures, and near-miss incidents.  Mishaps involving explosive support equipment are covered by the same investigation procedures.  The Safety Department performs an immediate investigation to assess the nature and degree of the mishap and the safety of the accident area.  Within 24 hours of the incident, the cognizant division director must prepare an investigation report for the Safety Department.  The Commander approves process restart when personnel injury is involved or the damage exceeds $10,000.  The Safety Department approves restart when no injuries are involved and the damage is less than $10,000.  The cognizant department head must address the findings of the investigations.  The Safety Department must prepare a summary of lessons learned that can be incorporated into employee training.  Recommended corrective actions are entered into a deficiency abatement log maintained by the Safety Department.  Progress on corrective actions is monitored quarterly.



The Safety Department and the supervisor of the personnel involved investigate occupational fatalities, injuries, illnesses, and near-miss incidents and prepare a report of the incident.  The division director and department head shall review the report and recommend any corrective actions.  Lost time i

ncidents require a command level review of the adequacy of OSH standards and recommended corrective actions.  The Safety Department tracks occupational injuries and illnesses.   The facility posts an annual summary report of occupational injuries and illnesses for review by all employees.



Employee Participation



Employees are involved in the risk management program elements through such avenues as training and committee or council membership.  The facility has an OSH council that includes employee union representation.  The council meets quarterly to review outstanding OSH issues and metrics.  The facility also has an explosive safety council with union representation and a similar purpose of review related to explosive safety.  Each department involved in hazardous operations must have it's own OSH committee.  These committees are to assure adequate OSH representation of all employees in the department. The facility safety manual devotes a chapter to a process for employees to report unsafe working conditions in accordance with OPNAVINST 5100.23.  The risk management plan will be supplied to the affected office for employees to review.  The facility OSH program is coordinated with the employee union.



Hot Work Permits



The facility's work permit program is outlined in the safety manual.  All work is done in compliance with 29 CFR 1910 and OPNAVINST 5100.23.  Operating personnel must decontaminate any explosive equipment or buildings prior to any repairs or maintenance.  The supervisor of the repair or maintenance crew must obtain a work permit from the Safety Department prior to beginning any work.  The crew leader or supervisor, the building supervisor and a safety inspector must inspect and approve the work area and the work to be performed.  All three parties must sign the work permit.



Contractors



The facility's contractor safety program is set forth in a separate chapter of the facility safety manual.  All solicitations for contracts include a co

py of the facility safety requirements.  Contracts include a requirement for communication of the hazards associated with materials at the facility.  Contracting officers are required to have contractors acknowledge receipt of the requirements and that they understand them.  The contracting officer is to maintain a safety performance plan for the duration of any contract.  The safety plan is a contract submittal requirement.  Pre-performance meetings are held to discuss safety and security concerns of both the contractor and facility.  Meeting attendance by representatives of fire protection, security, occupational safety and health, and the work area are required.  The Safety Department must approve all contract work through the issuance of a work permit.  The safety officer that signed the work permit will periodically check the work site for safety issues.  The Safety Department also performs monthly inspections of contractor work sites.



Emergency Response Program



The facility's Fire Department has an emergency management plan that complies with the National Response Team's Integrated Contingency Plan Guidance.  Facility sites where there is potential for damage to the environment from the spill of oil or a hazardous substance are required to have spill plans.  Hazardous waste accumulation sites are also required to have spill plans.  These site specific spill plans are kept in the environmental office, with the Fire Department, and the cognizant office.  Important sections of the plan are kept at the site.  The plans are reviewed annually and resubmitted every four years regardless of any changes.  The local emergency agencies have a copy of our contingency plan with our Part B permit.  There are procedures to notify the public and a list of media to contact in case of an emergency.  The facility has an on scene operation team (OSOT) to respond to hazardous material situations.
